title: WeWork's IPO-killer gives his Afterpay verdict
text:
“This is 700 million red flags that spell words on the field of a football field at halftime,” Galloway wrote. “[It says] ‘Get me the hell out of this stock, but YOU should buy some.’”

Galloway published his initial WeWork take – entitled WeWTF – on August 16. On September 20, as the valuation attached to the business tumbled, Galloway posted a follow-up, saying the business had “gone from unicorn to distressed asset in 30 days.” Ten days later, WeWork officially pulled the IPO.

Galloway was back for more last weekend, arguing the WeWork episode had helped the market discern between overvalued unicorns – a list he says includes Uber, Twitter, Pinterest and Slack – and companies that could lose 80 per cent of their value or disappear.

His list of the latter includes WeWork, Indian hotel group OYO, Uber rival Lyft and stock trading app Robinhood.

But Galloway has also released a Youtube video examining the rapid rise of the buy now, pay later sector in the US, which is trailing a year or so behind the sector’s Australian expansion.

And ASX tech darling Afterpay was one of the three businesses under the microscope, along with its US rival, Affirm, and Swedish rival Klarrna (in which Commonwealth Bank has a stake).

While Galloway’s claim that the valuation of Afterpay and its two rivals could halve in the next 12 months is the obvious attention-grabber, he is far from dismissive of their success, pointing that 16 per cent of the 75 US retailers he tracks – including giant Wal-Mart – have already adopted these payment products.

Advertisement

He says there are two key drivers of the sector’s growth. Firstly, younger American consumers particularly cash strapped, with half of 30-year-olds making less than their parents did at their age. In this environment, four instalments of $20 over eight weeks, interest-free, can look less intimidating than one $80 amount on a credit card bill.

The other benefit is for retailers. “[Credit] approval at the point of purchase increases basket sizes by 20 per cent to 30 per cent,” Galloway says, praising what he describes as “savvy marketing”.

Of course, there’s a big “but” here.

“Affirm, Afterpay and Klarna have smart businesses that capitalise on key consumer trends, but they have one major problem – a lack of moats,” he says, referring to the Warren Buffett idea that strong businesses have competitive “moats” that make them hard to displace.

“These buy now, pay later have puddles rather than moats, which credit card companies can likely breach and step over.”

Stocks 'will likely be halved in the next 12 months'

Galloway argues that Visa’s announcement in July that it would enter the buy now, pay later space later this year was very bad news for Afterpay, Affirm and Klarna.

He says card companies have strong instalment products in other markets – Brazil is a good example, where instalment-type products account for 50 per cent of the consumer credit market – and is it likely that Mastercard quickly follows Visa’s lead.

Advertisement

“Brand identity goes a long way, and these companies have been explicit in targeting young professionals without credit cards. But they are likely over-valued,” Galloway says, arguing that while Mastercard and Visa are valued at 18 times and 19 times revenue respectively, Afterpay is trading on 37 times.

“It’s suspect that Afterpay, whose clientele is Mastercard and Visa rejects, should trade at twice their multiples.

“These stocks will likely be halved in the next 12 months as Visa rolls out its product and the entire market begins to shudder with yet another duopoly firm crushing competition.”

Given Galloway’s prescient assessment of WeWork, you’d be silly to discount this view. And clearly, Mastercard and Visa are unlikely to cede this turf to disrupters.

But Galloway’s prediction for Afterpay’s share price feels more like a general statement his view on the sector rather than a detailed assessment of its business performance.

It doesn’t appear to take into account, for example, Afterpay’s growth trajectory in Australia (where an increasing proportion of its transactions are generated in-store rather than online, emphasising its ability to generate precious foot traffic for struggling retailers) or the potential for the business it is building in Britain.

Galloway might also overestimate how easy it will be for Mastercard and Visa to make up ground on established players, even given the power of their duopoly.

But what’s fascinating is Galloway’s prescription for these disrupters who are about to be disrupted: Go harder and faster.

“They are trading at exceptional multiples, they should be making acquisitions and massively reinvesting in the business and the relationships and turning those rivers and puddles into real moats,” Galloway says.

It’s something for Afterpay investors to ponder: Is growth or earnings more important for the company right now?
description: NYU professor Scott Galloway slammed WeWork's float and is now targeting the buy now, pay later sector, one with smart businesses and one big problem.
